when_to_say: Used to express gratitude in informal settings.
example: ありがとう、手伝ってくれて！ (arigatou, tetsudatte kurete!) - Thank you for helping me!

when_to_say: Used when parting for an extended time.
example: さようなら、また会いましょう！ (sayounara, mata aimashou!) - Goodbye, see you again!

when_to_say: Used to describe tasty food.
example: このケーキは美味しいです！ (kono keeki wa oishii desu!) - This cake is delicious!

when_to_say: Used to affirm or agree.
example: はい、分かりました！ (hai, wakarimashita!) - Yes, I understand!

when_to_say: Used to disagree or decline.
example: いいえ、結構です。 (iie, kekkou desu.) - No, thank you.

when_to_say: Used to apologize or get someone's attention.
example: すみません、お手洗いはどこですか？ (sumimasen, otearai wa doko desu ka?) - Excuse me, where is the restroom?

when_to_say: Used to greet someone in the daytime.
example: こんにちは、元気ですか？ (konnichiwa, genki desu ka?) - Hello, how are you?

when_to_say: Used to refer to someone you are close to.
example: 彼は私の友達です。 (kare wa watashi no tomodachi desu.) - He is my friend.

when_to_say: Used to describe enjoyable experiences.
example: このゲームは楽しいです！ (kono geemu wa tanoshii desu!) - This game is fun!

when_to_say: Used to refer to relatives.
example: 私の家族は5人です。 (watashi no kazoku wa gonin desu.) - My family has five members.

when_to_say: Used to greet someone in the morning.
example: おはよう、元気？ (ohayou, genki?) - Good morning, how are you?

when_to_say: Used to greet someone in the evening.
example: こんばんは、今日は寒いですね。 (konbanwa, kyou wa samui desu ne.) - Good evening, it's cold today.

when_to_say: Used when making a polite request.
example: 水をお願いします。 (mizu o onegai shimasu.) - Water, please.

when_to_say: Used to describe something impressive.
example: この映画はすごい！ (kono eiga wa sugoi!) - This movie is amazing!

when_to_say: Used to say you're fine or something is okay.
example: 私は大丈夫です。 (watashi wa daijoubu desu.) - I'm okay.

when_to_say: Used to say you understand something.
example: 分かりましたか？ (wakarimashita ka?) - Do you understand?

when_to_say: Used to refer to a pet or animal.
example: この犬は可愛いです！ (kono inu wa kawaii desu!) - This dog is cute!

when_to_say: Used to refer to a pet or animal.
example: 私は猫が好きです。 (watashi wa neko ga suki desu.) - I like cats.

when_to_say: Used to express strong liking or love.
example: 彼女が大好きです。 (kanojo ga daisuki desu.) - I love her.

when_to_say: Used to describe a calm or silent environment.
example: この場所は静かです。 (kono basho wa shizuka desu.) - This place is quiet.

when_to_say: Used to describe someone’s well-being or energy level.
example: 今日は元気ですか？ (kyou wa genki desu ka?) - Are you feeling energetic today?

word: ありがとうございます
when_to_say: Used to express formal gratitude.
example: プレゼントをありがとうございます！ (purezento o arigatou gozaimasu!) - Thank you very much for the gift!

when_to_say: Used to respond politely when someone thanks you.
example: ありがとう！ - どういたしまして！ (arigatou! - dou itashimashite!) - Thank you! - You're welcome!

when_to_say: Used to describe weather or objects with high temperature.
example: 今日は暑いですね！ (kyou wa atsui desu ne!) - It's hot today, isn't it?

when_to_say: Used to describe cold weather.
example: 外は寒いです。 (soto wa samui desu.) - It's cold outside.

when_to_say: Used to describe something aesthetically pleasing.
example: この花は美しいです。 (kono hana wa utsukushii desu.) - This flower is beautiful.

when_to_say: Used to describe speed or early timing.
example: 電車は早いですね。 (densha wa hayai desu ne.) - The train is fast, isn't it?

when_to_say: Used to describe slowness or being late.
example: 彼は遅いです。 (kare wa osoi desu.) - He is slow.

when_to_say: Used to talk about shops or stores.
example: その店は安いです。 (sono mise wa yasui desu.) - That shop is cheap.

when_to_say: Used to describe something simple.
example: このテストは簡単です。 (kono tesuto wa kantan desu.) - This test is easy.

when_to_say: Used to refer to someone you have a friendly relationship with.
example: 彼は私の友達です。 (kare wa watashi no tomodachi desu.) - He is my friend.

when_to_say: Used to talk about family members.
example: 家族と旅行しました。 (kazoku to ryokou shimashita.) - I traveled with my family.

when_to_say: Used to address or refer to a teacher or mentor.
example: 先生に質問があります。 (sensei ni shitsumon ga arimasu.) - I have a question for the teacher.

when_to_say: Used to refer to someone studying in school or university.
example: 彼女は学生です。 (kanojo wa gakusei desu.) - She is a student.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the animal cat.
example: この猫は可愛いです。 (kono neko wa kawaii desu.) - This cat is cute.

when_to_say: Used to refer to the animal dog.
example: その犬はとても大きいです。 (sono inu wa totemo ookii desu.) - That dog is very big.

when_to_say: Used to talk about a place of education.
example: 毎日学校に行きます。 (mainichi gakkou ni ikimasu.) - I go to school every day.

when_to_say: Used to talk about a medical facility.
example: 母は病院で働いています。 (haha wa byouin de hataraiteimasu.) - My mother works at a hospital.

when_to_say: Used to describe something challenging.
example: この質問は難しいです。 (kono shitsumon wa muzukashii desu.) - This question is difficult.

when_to_say: Used to refer to trains for transportation.
example: 毎朝電車に乗ります。 (maiasa densha ni norimasu.) - I ride the train every morning.

when_to_say: Used when expressing support or motivation to someone.
example: 友達の励ましに感謝しています。 (tomodachi no hagemashi ni kansha shiteimasu.) - I am grateful for my friend's encouragement.

when_to_say: Used when talking about regular practices or traditions.
example: 健康的な習慣を身につけたいです。 (kenkouteki na shuukan o mi ni tsuketai desu.) - I want to develop healthy habits.

when_to_say: Used when discussing putting in hard work towards a goal.
example: 成功には努力が必要です。 (seikou ni wa doryoku ga hitsuyou desu.) - Success requires effort.

when_to_say: Used when describing taking on a difficult task or goal.
example: 新しい挑戦を楽しみにしています。 (atarashii chousen o tanoshimi ni shiteimasu.) - I am looking forward to a new challenge.

when_to_say: Used when discussing the importance or significance of something.
example: その経験は大きな価値があります。 (sono keiken wa ookina kachi ga arimasu.) - That experience has great value.

when_to_say: Used when talking about a chance to do something.
example: 素晴らしい機会をありがとうございます。 (subarashii kikai o arigatou gozaimasu.) - Thank you for the wonderful opportunity.

when_to_say: Used when referring to personal or organizational development.
example: 失敗から成長することができます。 (shippai kara seichou suru koto ga dekimasu.) - You can grow from failures.

when_to_say: Used when expressing belief in one’s abilities.
example: 自信を持って行動しましょう。 (jishin o motte koudou shimashou.) - Let's act with confidence.

when_to_say: Used when discussing aspirations or goals.
example: 夢を叶えるために努力しています。 (yume o kanaeru tame ni doryoku shiteimasu.) - I am working hard to achieve my dream.

when_to_say: Used when expressing expectations for a positive outcome.
example: 希望を持ち続けることが大切です。 (kibou o mochitsuzukeru koto ga taisetsu desu.) - It is important to keep holding on to hope.

when_to_say: Used to refer to someone you share a close bond with.
example: 友達と映画に行きました。 (tomodachi to eiga ni ikimashita.) - I went to the movies with a friend.

when_to_say: Used to refer to your family members collectively.
example: 家族と旅行に行きます。 (kazoku to ryokou ni ikimasu.) - I am going on a trip with my family.

when_to_say: Used to address or refer to a teacher or mentor.
example: 先生に質問しました。 (sensei ni shitsumon shimashita.) - I asked the teacher a question.

when_to_say: Used to refer to an educational institution.
example: 学校で勉強します。 (gakkou de benkyou shimasu.) - I study at school.

when_to_say: Used to refer to one’s occupation or tasks.
example: 今日は仕事が忙しいです。 (kyou wa shigoto ga isogashii desu.) - Work is busy today.

when_to_say: Used to talk about the act of learning or studying.
example: 日本語を勉強しています。 (nihongo o benkyou shiteimasu.) - I am studying Japanese.

when_to_say: Used to talk about one’s leisure interests.
example: 私の趣味は読書です。 (watashi no shumi wa dokusho desu.) - My hobby is reading books.

when_to_say: Used to talk about going on a journey or trip.
example: 家族と旅行に行きました。 (kazoku to ryokou ni ikimashita.) - I went on a trip with my family.

when_to_say: Used to refer to a particular moment or duration.
example: 時間がありますか？ (jikan ga arimasu ka?) - Do you have time?

when_to_say: Used to refer to breaks or vacation days.
example: 来週は休みです。 (raishuu wa yasumi desu.) - I have a holiday next week.

when_to_say: Used to describe or inquire about the weather conditions.
example: 今日の天気は晴れです。 (kyou no tenki wa hare desu.) - Today's weather is sunny.

when_to_say: Used to describe someone’s physical or emotional well-being.
example: お元気ですか？ (ogenki desu ka?) - How are you?

when_to_say: Used to express that something or someone is okay.
example: 私は大丈夫です。 (watashi wa daijoubu desu.) - I’m okay.

when_to_say: Used to describe a state of being occupied with tasks.
example: 今日は忙しいです。 (kyou wa isogashii desu.) - I am busy today.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is easy to do.
example: この問題は簡単です。 (kono mondai wa kantan desu.) - This problem is easy.

when_to_say: Used to describe something that is complex or difficult to understand.
example: この仕組みは複雑です。 (kono shikumi wa fukuzatsu desu.) - This mechanism is complicated.

when_to_say: Used to express concern or anxiety about something.
example: 心配しないでください。 (shinpai shinaide kudasai.) - Please don’t worry.

when_to_say: Used to describe something extraordinary or unique.
example: これは特別な日です。 (kore wa tokubetsu na hi desu.) - This is a special day.

when_to_say: Used when referring to forgetting something.
example: 宿題を忘れました。 (shukudai o wasuremashita.) - I forgot my homework.

when_to_say: Used to talk about recalling or learning something.
example: 新しい単語を覚えました。 (atarashii tango o oboemashita.) - I learned a new word.

when_to_say: Used when looking for something or someone.
example: 鍵を探しています。 (kagi o sagashiteimasu.) - I am searching for my keys.

when_to_say: Used when describing running or moving quickly.
example: 彼は毎朝公園で走ります。 (kare wa maiasa kouen de hashirimasu.) - He runs in the park every morning.

when_to_say: Used when opening doors, windows, or containers.
example: 窓を開けてください。 (mado o akete kudasai.) - Please open the window.

when_to_say: Used when closing doors, windows, or containers.
example: ドアを閉めてください。 (doa o shimete kudasai.) - Please close the door.

when_to_say: Used when talking about paying money.
example: 現金で払います。 (genkin de haraimasu.) - I will pay in cash.

when_to_say: Used when referring to watching or observing something.
example: 映画を見ましたか？ (eiga o mimashita ka?) - Did you watch the movie?

when_to_say: Used when referring to writing words, letters, or other forms of text.
example: 彼は日記を書くのが好きです。 (kare wa nikki o kaku no ga suki desu.) - He likes to write in his diary.

when_to_say: Used when referring to swimming in water.
example: 彼女は毎週プールで泳ぎます。 (kanojo wa maishuu puuru de oyogimasu.) - She swims at the pool every week.

when_to_say: Used when talking about speaking or communicating.
example: 日本語を話せますか？ (nihongo o hanasemasu ka?) - Can you speak Japanese?

when_to_say: Used when talking about making or creating something.
example: 私はケーキを作ります。 (watashi wa keeki o tsukurimasu.) - I make cakes.

when_to_say: Used when describing a difficult or ambitious task.
example: 新しい挑戦に挑みます。 (atarashii chousen ni idomimasu.) - I will take on a new challenge.

when_to_say: Used in formal settings for discussions or debates.
example: その問題について議論しました。 (sono mondai ni tsuite giron shimashita.) - We had a discussion about the issue.

when_to_say: Used when describing conflicting statements or actions.
example: 彼の言葉には矛盾があります。 (kare no kotoba ni wa mujun ga arimasu.) - There is a contradiction in his words.

when_to_say: Used when discussing the process of making something better.
example: 仕事のプロセスを改善しました。 (shigoto no purosesu o kaizen shimashita.) - We improved the work process.

when_to_say: Used when making an educated guess or hypothesis.
example: 彼の言葉から推測しました。 (kare no kotoba kara suisoku shimashita.) - I inferred from his words.

when_to_say: Used when discussing making an idea or plan a reality.
example: その計画を実現するのは難しいです。 (sono keikaku o jitsugen suru no wa muzukashii desu.) - Implementing that plan is difficult.

when_to_say: Used in discussions about variety or differences.
example: 多様性を尊重する社会を作りたい。 (tayousei o sonchou suru shakai o tsukuritai.) - I want to create a society that respects diversity.

when_to_say: Used when referring to flourishing or thriving conditions.
example: その国は経済的に繁栄しています。 (sono kuni wa keizaiteki ni han'ei shiteimasu.) - That country is economically prosperous.

when_to_say: Used when referring to revolutionary changes or ideas.
example: 革新が新しい技術を生み出しました。 (kakushin ga atarashii gijutsu o umidashimashita.) - Innovation created new technology.

when_to_say: Used when talking about overcoming difficulties or obstacles.
example: 困難を克服しました。 (konnan o kokufuku shimashita.) - I overcame the difficulties.

when_to_say: Used when describing actions or systems that can be maintained over time.
example: 持続可能なエネルギーを開発する必要があります。 (jizoku kanou na enerugii o kaihatsu suru hitsuyou ga arimasu.) - We need to develop sustainable energy.

when_to_say: Used when discussing the ability to convince others.
example: 彼女の話には説得力があります。 (kanojo no hanashi ni wa settoku ryoku ga arimasu.) - Her speech has persuasiveness.

when_to_say: Used when evaluating how trustworthy or dependable something is.
example: そのデータの信頼性を確認する必要があります。 (sono deeta no shinraisei o kakunin suru hitsuyou ga arimasu.) - We need to verify the reliability of that data.

when_to_say: Used when talking about adjusting to new circumstances.
example: 新しい環境に適応するのは難しいです。 (atarashii kankyou ni tekiou suru no wa muzukashii desu.) - Adapting to a new environment is difficult.

when_to_say: Used to describe revolutionary ideas or actions.
example: これは画期的な発見です。 (kore wa kakkiteki na hakken desu.) - This is a groundbreaking discovery.

when_to_say: Used when acknowledging efforts towards a cause or project.
example: 会社に多大な貢献をしました。 (kaisha ni tadai na kouken o shimashita.) - I made a significant contribution to the company.

when_to_say: Used when discussing mutual concessions in agreements.
example: 妥協することで合意に達しました。 (dakyou suru koto de goui ni tasshimashita.) - We reached an agreement through compromise.

when_to_say: Used in formal contexts about enforcing laws or executing plans.
example: 法律の執行が必要です。 (houritsu no shikkou ga hitsuyou desu.) - Law enforcement is necessary.

when_to_say: Used in discussions about equity or justice.
example: 公平性を保つことが重要です。 (kouheisei o tamotsu koto ga juuyou desu.) - Maintaining fairness is important.

when_to_say: Used when expressing the advantage or privilege gained.
example: その制度の恩恵を受けています。 (sono seido no onkei o uketeimasu.) - I am receiving the benefits of that system.
